questions.text: Which among the following is not an integral protein?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Cell adhesion molecules (CAMs), although involved in important membrane interactions, are often peripheral or loosely associated with the inner surface of the plasma membrane, and do not always span the lipid bilayer. Hence, they are not necessarily considered integral proteins.
  • Membrane proteins are broadly classified into:
    1. Integral proteins: These are embedded across the lipid bilayer and often span the membrane completely. Integral proteins include:
      • Ion channels (e.g., Na+/K+ channels) (Option A)
      • Carrier proteins (e.g., glucose transporters) (Option B)
      • G proteins (coupled to membrane receptors and signal transduction) (Option C)
    2. Peripheral proteins: These are attached only to one surface (either extracellular or cytoplasmic) of the membrane and do not penetrate through it. It includes:
      • Spectrin, ankyrin (in cytoskeleton-membrane anchoring)
      • Cytochrome c (mitochondrial membrane)
      • Cell adhesion molecules (CAMs)
    3. Lipid-Anchored Proteins: These are covalently attached to lipid molecules embedded in the membrane but do not enter the bilayer themselves. It includes:
      • GPI-anchored proteins (e.g., alkaline phosphatase)
      • Ras protein (involved in signal transduction)

questions.text: Among the list of following, which is not a molecular motor of cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Actin, though a cytoskeletal protein, is not a motor protein. It forms the structural filament (track) on which myosin moves. Hence, it lacks the ATP-driven motor function required to qualify as a molecular motor.
  • Molecular motor proteins are specialised ATPases that convert chemical energy (from ATP hydrolysis) into mechanical work.
  • They are essential for intracellular transport, vesicle movement, and chromosomal segregation.
  • All molecular motors share the following features:
    • A motor (head) domain that binds ATP and cytoskeletal elements.
    • A cargo-binding domain that attaches to organelles or vesicles.
    • Directionality, which allows them to move cargo along actin filaments or microtubules.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented to a paediatrician with abnormal liver growth, skin abnormalities, and congenital cataracts. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a connexin gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Connexins are integral membrane proteins that form gap junctions, which allow the exchange of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells.
  • Clouston syndrome (hidrotic ectodermal dysplasia) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the connexin 30 (GJB6 gene). It is an autosomal dominant disorder.

It is characterised by:

  • Alopecia (hair loss beginning in childhood or infancy)
  • Nail dystrophy (abnormalities in nail shape, texture, and colour)
  • Palmoplantar hyperkeratosis
  • Sometimes associated with cataract formation.

Diseases Associated with Connexin Mutations

Explanation of other options:

Tay-Sachs disease (Option A): A lysosomal storage disorder due to hexosaminidase A deficiency, causing ganglioside accumulation, primarily affecting the CNS.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (Option C): Also called Kartagener syndrome (Option D), is caused by defects in ciliary structure/proteins (e.g., dynein arms)

questions.text: Which of the following lipids, in addition to proteins, are major components of the eukaryotic cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The plasma membrane of eukaryotic cells is a dynamic structure made up of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates, with lipids and proteins being the main structural components.
  • The major lipid components include:
    • Phospholipids such as phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylserine, and phosphatidylethanolamine
    • Sphingomyelin, which contributes to membrane stability and signal transduction
    • Cholesterol, which plays a critical role in regulating membrane fluidity and integrity

Key Takeaway:

A typical plasma membrane is composed of approximately:

  • Lipids:40%
  • Proteins:50%
  • Carbohydrates:10%

choices.text: Mitochondria may have evolved from aerobic bacteria
Mitochondria help in the regulation of apoptosis
Almost 99% of proteins in the mitochondria are from mitochondrial DNA
The primary function of mitochondria is to produce ATP from oxidative phosphorylation

questions.text: Among the following statements, which is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Though mitochondria have their DNA (mtDNA), it codes for only 13 proteins, 22 tRNAs, and 2 rRNAs.
  • Over 99% of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA (not by mitochondrial DNA) and imported into mitochondria post-translation.
  • According to the endosymbiotic theory, mitochondria are thought to have evolved from aerobic bacteria engulfed by ancestral eukaryotic cells over a billion years ago. (Option A)
  • Mitochondria release cytochrome c and other pro-apoptotic factors, which help in the activation of caspases during apoptosis. (Option B)
  • The major function of mitochondria is the production of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation via the electron transport chain (ETC) and chemiosmosis. (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA):

  • Maternal Inheritance: mtDNA is exclusively inherited from the mother.
  • Smaller Genome: It's much smaller than nuclear DNA, containing only about 16,500 base pairs.
  • Essential Genes: mtDNA encodes essential genes for energy production.
  • High Mutation Rate: mtDNA mutates faster than nuclear DNA, making it useful for studying evolution and genetic diseases.

choices.text: Intercalated cells of the renal tubule

questions.text: Which of the following cells/organs contain proton pumps (H+-ATPase) that actively transport hydrogen ions against a concentration gradient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Proton pumps (H+-ATPase) are examples of primary active transport mechanisms, utilising ATP to move hydrogen ions against a steep concentration gradient.
  • Parietal cells of the gastric glands contain H+/K+ ATPase pumps in their apical membranes. These secrete hydrogen ions into the lumen of the stomach, essential for maintaining an acidic pH (~1.0) for pepsinogen activation and digestion. (Option A)
  • Lysosomal membranes use H+-ATPase pumps to acidify the internal environment, which in turn activates acid hydrolases required for the degradation of cellular debris. (Option B)
  • Intercalated cells of the distal renal tubules and collecting ducts actively secrete H+ ions into the tubular lumen. This is critical for acid-base homeostasis and for maintaining urinary pH. (Option C)

questions.text: A 34-year-old female was diagnosed with breast cancer. She was prescribed paclitaxel, a chemotherapeutic agent. The targeted cytoskeleton by paclitaxel is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paclitaxel (Taxol) binds to and stabilises microtubules, preventing their depolymerisation.
  • This inhibits mitotic spindle formation, arresting cell division and leading to apoptosis in rapidly dividing cells like cancer cells.
  • The cytoskeleton is a structural network within the cytoplasm, composed of three main types of protein filaments:

questions.text: Which of the following cell adhesion molecules is calcium-dependent and facilitates cell-to-cell adhesion through homophilic interactions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cadherins are the only CAMs among the options that are calcium-dependent and mediate homophilic cell-to-cell adhesion, forming adherens junctions between epithelial cells.
  • Cell Adhesion Molecules (CAMs) are surface proteins that mediate cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions. They are vital in embryogenesis, tissue architecture, and inflammation.

The major types of CAMs are:

choices.text: Cell adhesion molecules provide stability to cells
Ion channels allow direct cell-to-cell communication
Peripheral type of proteins on the cell membrane
Each connexin is made up of six connexon subunits

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about connexins?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Connexins are integral membrane proteins that assemble to form gap junction channels.
  • These gap junctions allow ions and small molecules (<1000 Da) to pass directly between cells, playing a major role in electrical and metabolic coupling, especially in cardiac and smooth muscle fibres. Hence, allow direct cell-to-cell communication.
  • Connexins are not classified as cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). CAMs include integrins, cadherins, selectins, and IgG-superfamily proteins, which provide mechanical attachment but do not function as channels for communication. (Option A ruled out)
  • Connexins are integral membrane proteins, not peripheral proteins. They span the membrane and form pores that bridge two adjacent cells. (Option C ruled out)
  • Each connexon is made up of six connexin subunits, not the other way around. Two connexons, one from each adjacent cell, join to form a complete gap junction channel. (Option D ruled out) 

Key Takeaway:

Connexons in the membrane of the cell are lined up with each other to form gap junctions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male has a history of repetitive infections. He visited the infectious disease specialist for evaluation. It was found that a patient has a defect with calcium binding, which is involved in T cell activation. Identify the protein involved:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Calcineurin is a Ca²+/calmodulin-dependent serine/threonine phosphatase.
  • It dephosphorylates nuclear factors of activated T cells (NFAT), enabling their nuclear translocation and promoting transcription of interleukin-2 (IL-2), essential for T cell proliferation. Also known as protein phosphatase 3 (PP3).
  • Immunosuppressants like cyclosporin and tacrolimus inhibit calcineurin, suppressing T-cell activation.;

Explanation of other options:

Troponin (Option A) is a Ca²+ -binding regulatory protein involved in skeletal and cardiac muscle contraction. When Ca²+ binds, it allows interaction between actin and myosin by uncovering the myosin-binding site on actin.

Calbindin (Option B) is a calcium-binding protein located in intestinal epithelial cells. It facilitates calcium transport across the epithelium and prevents disruption of calcium signalling.
